subject: Re: [junit] Assert style
msgSnippet: ... I always put messages in an assert, initially I started with the true state, but after a while found it more communicative to use the failure state -
messageBody:
At 01:23 PM 26-01-01 -0500, David Corbin wrote:
>When you put a message in an assert(), does your message reflect the
>true state (indicating what you're actually asserting) or the failure
>state (which is when you actually see the message).

I always put messages in an assert, initially I started with the true
state, but after a while found it more communicative to use the failure
state - especially while dealing with unit tests on older code when
refactoring or adding functionality at a (much) later date.

As an aside, I would prefer the message to be after the asserted item/s as
it would be easier to see exactly what the assertion was, which would aid
communication IMO, particularly if you use descriptive names, e.g. ( the
word wrap will probably destroy the formatting but the assert string goes
on a separate line starting level with the accountLastUpdated on the first
example and vice versa on the second or if you are blessed with a larger
monitor they could all be on the same line):

assertEquals( accountLastUpdated, lastTransactionDate,
"Bank account last updated date is not the
same as the date of the last transaction" );

as opposed to:

assertEquals( "Bank account last updated date is not the same as
the date of the last transaction",
accountLastUpdated, lastTransactionDate );

I find it much easier to scan the asserts that way and the more asserts you
have, the more the messages obscure the items under test, but that could
just be me.

Robert
